pageData.text: Students will explore the effects of several factors on the genetic makeup of a population. They will learn to use the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium equations to calculate expected genotypic frequencies. Students will also understand the conditions necessary for a population to be in equilibrium and describe how natural populations deviate from these conditions.

Preparation - 15 minutes
Activity 1: Small Population Size and Genetic Drift - 60 minutes
Activity 2: Predation on Dominant Individuals - 60 minutes
Activity 3: Predation on Homozygous Recessive Individuals - 60 minutes

text: List the conditions necessary for the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium to occur.
Explain why natural populations are likely to deviate from these conditions.
Discuss the effect of these deviations on the ratios of <button class='glossary-text'>alleles</button> in a population.

pageData.text: Understanding <button class='glossary-text'>allele</button> frequency in a population can help us understand who is at risk for certain genetic diseases and why. An important example of this is sickle cell disease, which is one of the most common and well-studied genetic diseases in the world. Individuals who are <button class='glossary-text'>homozygous</button> <button class='glossary-text'>recessive</button> for sickle cell trait (SCT) have the disease, which causes red blood cells to become crescent-shaped under stress, causing them to form clots and die off more quickly. This leads to patients not getting enough oxygen to their tissues, causing intense pain and fatigue. Without intensive treatment, it can be fatal. Usually, the allele frequency of a trait like this would be quite rare in the population and very few individuals would end up being homozygous recessive. However, in some parts of Sub-Saharan Africa, up to 45% of the population carries SCT<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. This is because being a carrier of SCT helps protect against the parasite which causes malaria compared to those who are homozygous for the <button class='glossary-text'>dominant</button> allele. Therefore, allele frequency for SCT is much higher in areas with endemic malaria like Sub-Saharan Africa, the Middle East, and South Asia. Knowing the allele frequency of SCT in these areas can help people understand their or their children’s potential risk for sickle cell disease and may help connect them to life-saving resources and early interventions.

1Mulumba, L. L., & Wilson, L. (2015). Sickle cell disease among children in Africa: An integrative literature review and global recommendations. International Journal of Africa Nursing Sciences, 3, 56–64. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijans.2015.08.002

Sickle Cell Anemia by Ed Uthman is available under CC BY 2.0 at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/euthman/5610746554

pageData.desc: Red blood cells from someone with sickle cell disease, as seen through a microscope. Most cells are round in shape. Some cells are crescent-shaped.
pageData.altText: Red blood cells from someone with sickle cell disease, as seen through a microscope. Most cells are round in shape. Some cells are crescent-shaped.

pageData.text: Charles Darwin first published the theory of in the mid-1800s. His theory stated that species evolve over time, adapting to their environments. Natural selection is the differential success rate in the reproduction of different (observable characteristics) resulting from the interaction of the organisms with their environment. In other words, an organism that is well adapted to its environment has a better chance of reproducing and passing on its genes than does an organism that is poorly suited to that environment. At the time of Darwin’s first published theory, the mechanism for inheritance was only poorly understood.

pageData.subTitle: Genes and Alleles
pageData.text: The key to understanding the mechanisms of inheritance is the work of Gregor Mendel. Though Gregor Mendel was a contemporary of Darwin, there is no evidence that they were familiar with each other’s work. Mendel’s work focused on hybridization experiments, where organisms of one type were bred to organisms of another type. Working with pea plants, Mendel identified factors that controlled key traits in the plants. The term gene was not used until the early 20th century to describe the molecular unit of heredity, and the recognition that genes were composed of DNA did not occur until the middle part of that century.

Mendel described the factors as either or . Each organism has two versions of each gene: one inherited from each parent. These versions are called . For example, one of the traits described by Mendel in his pea plant experiments was flower color (Figure 1). The color of this flower might be determined by one gene, a gene that possesses two color variations—one allele for red and one allele for white. The flower receives one allele from each of its parents, and the combination of these alleles determines the color of the flower. If the inherited alleles are identical, or , then they express that color trait. Two “red” alleles make a flower red. Likewise, two “white” alleles make a flower white. When alleles of different types are combined (this is defined as ), only the dominant allele is expressed. For instance, if the “red” allele is dominant and the “white” allele is recessive, then the heterozygous flower will be red. Whether homozygous or heterozygous, the combination of alleles is called the organism’s , and the specific trait expressed by the genotype is the organism’s .

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Two mating events in flowers showing Mendelian inheritance for a single trait. In the first event, flowers with a red phenotype caused by a genotype of two red pigment alleles cross with flowers with a white phenotype caused by a genotype of two white alleles. This is the P generation. The resulting F1 generation consists 100% of red phenotype flowers caused by a genotype of one red pigment allele and one white allele. The red allele is dominant. The white allele is recessive and causes a lack of pigmentation. In the second event, flowers from the F1 generation cross. The resulting F2 generation consists of 25% red phenotype flowers caused by a genotype of two red pigment alleles, 50% red phenotype flowers caused by a genotype of one red pigment allele and one white allele, and 25% white phenotype flowers caused by a genotype of two white alleles. The recessive trait from the P generation reappears phenotypically in the F2 generation in individuals homozygous for that trait.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Two mating events in flowers showing Mendelian inheritance for a single trait. In the first event, flowers with a red phenotype caused by a genotype of two red pigment alleles cross with flowers with a white phenotype caused by a genotype of two white alleles. This is the P generation. The resulting F1 generation consists 100% of red phenotype flowers caused by a genotype of one red pigment allele and one white allele. The red allele is dominant. The white allele is recessive and causes a lack of pigmentation. In the second event, flowers from the F1 generation cross. The resulting F2 generation consists of 25% red phenotype flowers caused by a genotype of two red pigment alleles, 50% red phenotype flowers caused by a genotype of one red pigment allele and one white allele, and 25% white phenotype flowers caused by a genotype of two white alleles. The recessive trait from the P generation reappears phenotypically in the F2 generation in individuals homozygous for that trait.

pageData.text:
Alleles are usually denoted by a single letter, and the dominant allele is capitalized. Therefore, in the flower example above, the dominant allele for red can be written R and the recessive allele for white, r. The three possible combinations of these alleles, the genotypes, can be written:
  • R/R (homozygous dominant)
  • r/r (homozygous recessive)
  • R/r (heterozygous)
In this example (Figure 1), flowers with the red phenotype are expressed from two different genotypes, R/R and R/r, while flowers having the white phenotype will all have only the one genotype, r/r.

pageData.question: If B represents the dominant allele for dark brown hair, and b represents the recessive allele for light blond hair, what genotype does a person with blond hair have?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A recessive phenotype, in this case blond hair, can only be expressed if the genotype consists of only recessive alleles (b ).

pageData.question: Red (R ) is the dominant color for a flower and white (r ) is recessive. What color would a flower be with the genotype Rr?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If a trait follows simple Mendelian inheritance, the dominant allele (R ) will be expressed even if the second allele in the genotype is recessive (r ).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Alleles are usually denoted by a single letter, and the dominant allele is capitalized. Genotypes are combination of both alleles, so there are three possible combinations:
  • BB (homozygous dominant)
  • bb (homozygous recessive)
  • Bb (heterozygous)

Alleles are usually denoted by a single letter, and the dominant allele is capitalized. Genotypes are combination of both alleles, so there are three possible combinations:
  • BB (homozygous dominant)

  • Bb (heterozygous)

pageData.subTitle: Allelic Frequencies
pageData.text: The total aggregate of genes in a specific population is known as the <button class='glossary-text'>gene pool</button>. The relative proportion of <button class='glossary-text'>alleles</button> for a gene present in the gene pool is called the <button class='glossary-text'>allelic frequency</button>.

Suppose one red flower pollinates another red flower and produces 400 offspring. In this new population, 300 flowers are red and 100 are white. To calculate the allelic frequency, we must know the <button class='glossary-text'>genotypes</button> of the offspring.
We know that there are only two alleles possible for the population, so we can use the following equation:
wherep = the allelic frequency of Rq = the allelic frequency of r However, because we also know that each flower possesses two alleles, we may expand the equation further:
p x p = p2 = frequency of R/R in the population(p x q) + (q x p) = 2pq = frequency of R/r in the populationq x q = q2 = frequency of r/r in the population
The sum of the frequencies of each genotype must also equal 1 ():

pageData.desc: Equation 2: p squared plus 2 times p times q plus q squared equals 1
pageData.altText: Equation 2: p squared plus 2 times p times q plus q squared equals 1

pageData.text: We know that the 100 white flowers are of the genotype r/r since, in this example, white is only possible with this genotype. From this, we can determine that r/r makes up 25% of the population (100 white flowers/400 total flowers = 1 /4, or 0.25). Now we have a way to calculate q and then p, as follows:
Frequency of r/r in the population = q2 = 0.25q = √0.25q = 0.5
Since p + q = 1,Then p + 0.5 = 1p = 0.5In this example, the allelic frequency for p = 0.5 and for q = 0.5.

tableData.text: Proportion of dominant alleles in the population
Number of dominant alleles divided by the total number of alleles
Proportion of recessive alleles in the population
Number of recessive alleles divided by the total number of alleles
Proportion of homozygous dominant individuals in the population
Number of homozygous dominant individuals divided by the total number of individuals
Proportion of heterozygous individuals in the population
Number of heterozygous individuals divided by the total number of individuals
Proportion of homozygous recessive individuals in the population
Number of homozygous recessive individuals divided by the total number of individuals

pageData.subTitle: The Hardy-Weinberg Principle and Natural Selection
pageData.text: The Hardy-Weinberg Principle states that a population’s allelic frequencies will remain the same for each generation if the following conditions are met:

• The population is infinitely large.
  • There is completely random mating within the population.
  • There is no genetic mutation.
  • There is no immigration or emigration (movement of individuals in or out of the population).
  • There is no .
The state wherein a population’s allelic and genotypic frequencies remain constant over time is known as <button class='glossary-text'>genetic equilibrium</button>.

In nature, it is difficult to find a population at genetic equilibrium. This would indicate that the population is not changing or evolving. Ecosystems are in a constant state of flux due to environmental changes and competition between organisms for finite resources. Under these conditions, organisms must be able to adapt to these changes to survive. Natural selection is the mechanism that allows the organisms that are best suited for an environment to have the best chance of mating and passing on their genes. Natural selection can happen in many different ways. For example, it can happen when a wildebeest in Africa is faster than another wildebeest and avoids becoming a lion’s prey, several cold-tolerant birds manage to survive an early winter, or a certain flower produces more nectar and attracts more bees than the neighboring flowers. In each of these cases, there is a difference in the organism’s genes that gives it an advantage over others in the population. Due to the environment in which the organism lives, these advantages increase the organism’s chances of surviving, reproducing, and passing on its genes. Ultimately, survival is dependent on a variety of factors, only one of which is any particular gene. A bird may be very brightly colored and therefore easier for predators to find, but if it is also very fast or more likely to find a mate then it may be able to pass on its genes despite having any particular harmful trait.

pageData.subTitle: The Peppered Moth Question
pageData.text: Another example of involves peppered moths (Biston betularia) of 19th-century England. Before the Industrial Revolution, scientists commonly found light-colored peppered moths but would occasionally find a darker moth (Figure 2). By the late 1800s, however, it was clear that dark-colored moths were becoming more common in the woods surrounding industrial areas. In areas far from the industries, the light-colored moth was still the prevalent . Why was there a change in the coloration of certain moth populations? In the 1950s, a physician named H. B. D. Kettlewell wanted to answer this question. Kettlewell knew that peppered moths are nocturnal and that they rest on trees during the day. He theorized that pollution from the factories altered the surrounding woods, and in particular, that soot from the factories was killing the light-colored lichen growing on the trees. Predators such as birds could now easily find the light-colored moths that had once been camouflaged by the lichen. In contrast, the dark-colored moths that once stood out against the lichen now blended well with the dark tree bark and were not preyed upon. This investigation examines the impact a change in the environment can have on the frequencies of a given in a population.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Two phenotypes of light peppered moth. One moth is light in color. A second moth is dark in color.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Two phenotypes of light peppered moth. One moth is light in color. A second moth is dark in color.

pageData.question: Which of the following represents the proportion of heterozygous individuals in a population when calculating allelic frequencies of a population in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A heterozygous allelic frequency must have p and q represented in the expression.

pageData.question: Which of the following represents the proportion of all homozygous dominant individuals in the population?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: p represents the frequency of dominant alleles in the population, while p2 represents the frequency of the homozygous dominant genotype.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for activities 1 and 2 of the investigation. To prepare, punch out the moths from the sheet and set up the moths in the environments. In activity 1, calculate the actual phenotypic and genotypic frequencies, the allelic frequencies and the theoretical genotypic frequencies. Then, randomly remove some of the moths and calculate the alleles passing to the next generation. Then, randomly mate the moths and determine the alleles present in the next generation. You will complete this for all 4 generations. In activity 2, replace the moths in the environment and create <button class='glossary-text'>allele</button> pairs for the moths. Next, calculate the actual phenotypic and genotypic frequencies, the allelic frequencies and the theoretical genotypic frequencies. Then, remove some of the black moths and calculate the alleles passing to the next generation. Then, determine the alleles present in the next generation. You will complete this for all 4 generations. Then, continue on to activity 3.
pageData.desc: A procedural workflow for activity of the investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, replace the moths in the environment and create allele pairs for the moths. Next, calculate the actual phenotypic and genotypic frequencies, the allelic frequencies and the theoretical genotypic frequencies. Then, remove some of the white moths and calculate the alleles passing to the next generation. Then, determine the alleles present in the next generation. You will complete this for all 4 generations.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which organisms are considered successful according to natural selection?

options.text: The organisms that reproduce are the most successful.
The organisms that live the longest are the most successful.
The organisms that are the strongest are the most successful.
The organisms that look like others in their population are the most successful.
The organisms that can live in multiple habitats are the most successful.

assestmentData.question: Who’s work focused on hybridization experiments using pea plants where organisms of one type are bred to organisms of another type?

The gene that produces pigment in the petals of a pea flower can either produce purple pigment or no pigment at all. Which of the following terms best describes these different versions of the same gene?
If a flower receives a yellow dominant allele from one parent, and a blue recessive allele from the other parent, the flower will be yellow.  What term best describes this combination of alleles?
If R represents the brown eye color allele and r represents the green eye color allele, what combination of these letters represents a person with green eyes?
Which of the following is NOT a condition of the Hardy-Weinberg Principle?

options.text: There is no immigration or emigration.
Mating within the population is completely random.

assestmentData.question: The sum of the frequencies of each genotype in a population must equal which value?
One yellow flower pollinates a second yellow flower and produces 150 offspring: 100 yellow flowers (Y) and 50 purple flowers (y). What is the frequency of the y allele in the offspring generation?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the activities.
Obtain all the materials.
Punch out the moths from the sheet.
Place 45 white moths and 5 black moths on the white environment sheet. These represent the <button class='glossary-text'>phenotypes</button> of the first generation.
The white is the allele, so the only way to have a white phenotype is to be recessive (b/b). Stack another white moth on top of each white moth. Now the is represented by the two moths.
The black phenotype can come from an individual that is homozygous (B/B) or (B/b). We have no way of knowing which one by looking at the moth.

Drop the remaining moths gently onto the table (off to the side) so that they fall randomly on either the moths’ black side or white side. Randomly assign a white or a black allele to each black moth by drawing blindly from the remaining moths and placing the drawn moth under a black moth already on the environment sheet. Now all the moths have both a phenotype (the color of the moth showing) and a genotype (the combination of colors in each moth “stack”). Each moth is represented by two moth cutouts.

In Activity 1, you will use simulated moths to model the effects of a small population size and genetic drift on the <button class='glossary-text'>allele</button> frequencies of a population. You will calculate the actual and theoretical allelic frequencies over multiple generations.

pages.title:
A
 Buffering Capacity of Soil (9 steps)
pages.pageTitle: Small Population Size and Genetic Drift (13 steps)

typeBefore.text: Because we are using a small population to examine the effect of <button class='glossary-text'>natural selection</button> on <button class='glossary-text'>allele</button> frequency, we will first examine the effect of violating the first of the conditions necessary for the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. Because this is a <button class='glossary-text'>stochastic</button> (random) effect, it may be beneficial to compare results with your classmates.

pageData.text: Record the number of black moths and white moths in Data Table 1. These are the Generation 1 in the population.

Calculate the phenotypic frequency of black moths by dividing the number of black moths by the total number of moths. Record the result for Generation 1 phenotypic frequency in Data Table 1. Then repeat to calculate the phenotypic frequency with the white moths, and record the result in Data Table 1.
Count the number of B/B moths, B/b moths, and b/b moths. Be sure to include all 50 individuals. These are the number of individuals with each for Generation 1. Record these in Data Table 1.

Calculate the proportion of the population with each genotype (the actual genotypic frequency) for Generation 1 by dividing the number of individuals with each genotype by the total number of individuals (50). Record this value in Data Table 1. The proportion of moths with the genotype b/b is q2. It is also equal to the phenotypic frequency of the white trait, because the only allele combination that can result in a white moth is b/b.
Calculate q by taking the square root of q2. Record this under the Generation 1 “q” value in Data Table 2.

Use the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium equation (p + q = 1) to calculate p, substituting the calculated q value into the formula and solving for p. Record this under the “p” value (theoretical ) in Data Table 2. You now have the allelic frequencies of Generation 1.
Now, use these allelic frequencies to calculate the theoretical (or expected) genotypic frequencies (p2 = B/B, 2pq = B/b, and q2 = b/b) for Generation 1. Record the results in Data Table 2.
Randomly remove 10 moths from the environment sheet. These represent moths that have failed to reproduce. In this example, failure to reproduce is a matter of chance and not related to fitness.

Record the number of black and white alleles remaining on the sheet in Data Table 3. Divide the number of black alleles by the total number of alleles (80). Record this in Data Table 3 as the frequency of black alleles passing to the next generation. Repeat for the white alleles.

The number of moths in the population is not going to change (the losses are going to be replaced by additional births) so you will have the number of each allele that will be added back in the next generation. To do this, multiply the frequency of black alleles by the number of alleles to be added back, in this case 20. Repeat for the white allele. Record these in Data Table 3.
Add the 20 reserved alleles back to the environment sheet using the numbers calculated in the previous step. Gently scramble all the moths without flipping any over.

Use these alleles to form the next generation. Closing or averting your eyes, randomly choose two cutouts to form a new pair from the table. This represents a random mating event. Place the pair on the black environment sheet with the black allele (if present) on top. This represents a single individual moth with the phenotype showing. Repeat this process until all the alleles have been paired.
Repeat Steps 1 through 12 for Generations 2, 3, and 4.

In Activity 2, you will use simulated moths to model the effects of predation on phenotypically <button class='glossary-text'>dominant</button> individuals on the <button class='glossary-text'>allele</button> frequencies of a population. You will calculate the actual and theoretical allelic frequencies over multiple generations.

typeBefore.text: In this activity, you will examine the effect that <button class='glossary-text'>natural selection</button> can have on the presence of a <button class='glossary-text'>dominant</button> <button class='glossary-text'>allele</button> in a population. Here, the dominant gene (black) is harmful to those moths that have it, because it causes them to stand out on the light-colored trees, represented by the white environment sheet.

pageData.text: Place 45 white moths and 5 black moths on the white environment sheet. These represent the <button class='glossary-text'>phenotypes</button> of Generation 1.
The white allele is the allele, so the only way to have a white phenotype is to be recessive (b/b). To represent this, stack another white moth on top of each white moth.
Either place the remaining moths in a bag or drop them gently onto the table so that they fall randomly on either the moths’ black side or white side.
Randomly assign a white or a black allele to each black moth by drawing blindly from the remaining moths and placing the drawn moth under a black moth already on the white environment sheet.
Record the number of black and white moths in Data Table 4. These are the Generation 1 phenotypes in the population.

Calculate the phenotypic frequency of black moths by dividing the number of black moths by the total number of moths. Record the result for Generation 1 phenotypic frequency in Data Table 4. Then repeat to calculate the phenotypic frequency with the white moths, and record the result in Data Table 4.
Count the number of B/B moths, B/b moths, and b/b moths. Be sure to include all 50 individuals. These are the number of individuals with each for Generation 1. Record these in Data Table 4.

Calculate the proportion of the population with each genotype (the actual genotypic frequency) for Generation 1 by dividing the number of individuals with each genotype by the total number of individuals (50). Record this value in Data Table 4. The proportion of moths with the genotype b/b is q2. It is also equal to the phenotypic frequency of the white trait, because the only allele combination that can result in a white moth is b/b.
Calculate q by taking the square root of q2. Record this under the Generation 1 “q” value in Data Table 5.

Use the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium equation (p + q = 1) to calculate p, substituting the calculated q value into the formula and solving for p. Record this under the “p” value (theoretical ) in Data Table 5. You now have the allelic frequencies of Generation 1.
Now, use these allelic frequencies to calculate the theoretical (or expected) genotypic frequencies (p2 = B/B, 2pq = B/b, and q2 = b/b) for Generation 1. Record the results in Data Table 5.

Remove half of the black moths (round up if there is an odd number of moths) from the white environment sheet. These represent moths that do not blend into their environment and were easier to find, therefore more likely to be eaten by predators.

Remove enough white moths so that the total number of moths removed is 10 (i.e., if you removed 2 black moths, you would remove 8 white moths for a total of 10). Predation can still occur on moths that blend into their environment. Predators will remove the easiest to find moths first but will also eat other moths if they happen to find them.

Record the number of black and white alleles remaining on the sheet in Data Table 6. Divide the number of black alleles by the total number of alleles (80). Record this in Data Table 6 as the frequency of black alleles passing to the next generation. Repeat for the white alleles.

The number of moths in the population is not going to change (the losses are going to be replaced by additional births) so that you will have the number of each allele that will be added back in the next generation. To do this, multiply the frequency of black alleles by the number of alleles to be added back, in this case 20. Repeat for the white allele. Record these in Data Table 6.
Add the 20 reserved alleles back to the environment sheet using the numbers calculated in the previous step. Gently scramble all the moths without flipping any over.

Use these alleles to form the next generation. Closing or averting your eyes, randomly choose two cutouts to form a new pair from the table. This represents a random mating event. Place the pair on the black environment sheet with the black allele (if present) on top. This represents a single individual moth with the phenotype showing. Repeat this process until all the alleles have been paired.
Repeat Steps 5 through 17 for Generations 2, 3, and 4 or until the black allele disappears from the population.

In Activity 3, you will use simulated moths to model the effects of predation on phenotypically <button class='glossary-text'>recessive</button> individuals on the <button class='glossary-text'>allele</button> frequencies of a population. You will calculate the actual and theoretical allelic frequencies over multiple generations.

pages.title:
A
 Buffering Capacity of Soil (9 steps)
pages.pageTitle: Predation on Homozygous Recessive Individuals (17 steps)

typeBefore.text: In this activity, you will consider how the population will change when the environment changes. The black environment represents the dark tree bark after the coal plants have killed the light-colored lichen.

pageData.text: Place 45 white moths and 5 black moths on the white environment sheet. These represent the <button class='glossary-text'>phenotypes</button> of Generation 1.
The white is the allele, so the only way to have a white phenotype is to be recessive (b/b). To represent this, stack another white moth on top of each white moth.
Either place the remaining moths in a bag or drop them gently onto the table so they fall randomly on either the moths’ black side or white side.
Randomly assign a white or a black allele to each black moth by drawing blindly from the remaining moths and placing the drawn moth under a black moth already on the white environment sheet.
Record the number of black and white moths in Data Table 7. These are the Generation 1 phenotypes in the population.

Calculate the phenotypic frequency of black moths for Generation 1 by dividing the number of black moths by the total number of moths. Record the result in Data Table 7. Then repeat to calculate the phenotypic frequency with the white moths, and record the result in Data Table 7.
Count the number of B/B moths, B/b moths, and b/b moths. Be sure to include all 50 individuals. These are the number of individuals with each for Generation 1. Record these in Data Table 7.

Calculate the proportion of the population with each genotype (the actual genotypic frequency) for Generation 1 by dividing the number of individuals with each genotype by the total number of individuals (50). Record this value in Data Table 7. The proportion of moths with the genotype b/b is q2. It is also equal to the phenotypic frequency of the white trait, because the only allele combination that can result in a white moth is b/b.
Calculate q by taking the square root of q2. Record this under the Generation 1 “q” value in Data Table 8.

Use the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium equation (p + q = 1) to calculate p, substituting the calculated q value into the formula and solving for p. Record this under the “p” value (theoretical ) in Data Table 8. You now have the allelic frequencies of Generation 1.
Now, use these allelic frequencies to calculate the theoretical (or expected) genotypic frequencies (p2 = B/B, 2pq = B/b, and q2 = b/b) for Generation 1. Record the results in Data Table 8.
Remove 10 of the white moths from the black environment sheet. These represent moths that do not blend into their environment and were easier to find,therefore more likely to be eaten by predators.

Record the number of black and white alleles remaining on the sheet in Data Table 9. Divide the number of black alleles by the total number of alleles (80). Record this in Data Table 9 as the frequency of black alleles passing to the next generation. Repeat for the white alleles.

The number of moths in the population is not going to change (the losses are going to be replaced by additional births) so you will have the number of each allele that will be added back in the next generation. To do this, multiply the frequency of black alleles by the number of alleles to be added back, in this case 20. Repeat for the white allele. Record these in Data Table 9.
Add the 20 reserved alleles back to the environment sheet using the numbers calculated in the previous step. Gently scramble all the moths without flipping any over.

Use these alleles to form the next generation. Closing or averting your eyes, randomly choose two cutouts to form a new pair from the table. This represents a random mating event. Place the pair on the black environment sheet with the black allele (if present) on top. This represents a single individual moth with the phenotype showing. Repeat this process until all the alleles have been paired.
Repeat Steps 5 through 16 for Generations 2, 3, and 4.

text: Discard the moth punchouts and environment sheets in the household trash or recycling.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

text: If natural selection favors the black moth, will the recessive b allele be eliminated from the population over time? Why or why not?
If natural selection favors the white moth, will the dominant B allele be eliminated from the population? Why or why not?
Why might the black allele have been present in the initial population?
Think of a condition under which a harmful dominant gene would not be eliminated from the population.
Is it possible for a population to exist in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium? Why or why not?
How might the results have differed in Activities 2 and 3 if 25 moths were eaten each generation rather than 10 moths?

pageData.content: Figure 1. Simple Mendelian inheritance in flowers
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Two mating events in flowers showing Mendelian inheritance for a single trait. In the first event, flowers with a red phenotype caused by a genotype of two red pigment alleles cross with flowers with a white phenotype caused by a genotype of two white alleles. This is the P generation. The resulting F1 generation consists 100% of red phenotype flowers caused by a genotype of one red pigment allele and one white allele. The red allele is dominant. The white allele is recessive and causes a lack of pigmentation. In the second event, flowers from the F1 generation cross. The resulting F2 generation consists of 25% red phenotype flowers caused by a genotype of two red pigment alleles, 50% red phenotype flowers caused by a genotype of one red pigment allele and one white allele, and 25% white phenotype flowers caused by a genotype of two white alleles. The recessive trait from the P generation reappears phenotypically in the F2 generation in individuals homozygous for that trait.
Equation 2: p squared plus 2 times p times q plus q squared equals 1

pageData.content: Table 1. Variables of the genotypic frequency equation

tableData.text: Proportion of dominant alleles in the population
Number of dominant alleles divided by the total number of alleles
Proportion of recessive alleles in the population
Number of recessive alleles divided by the total number of alleles
Proportion of homozygous dominant individuals in the population
Number of homozygous dominant individuals divided by the total number of individuals
Proportion of heterozygous individuals in the population
Number of heterozygous individuals divided by the total number of individuals
Proportion of homozygous recessive individuals in the population
Number of homozygous recessive individuals divided by the total number of individuals

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Two phenotypes of light peppered moth. One moth is light in color. A second moth is dark in color.

A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, you will prepare acidic water solutions and simulated acid rain. In activity 1, you will add the filter paper to the 4 Petri dishes, wet the filter papers with the designated pH solution and place the seeds in each dish. Then, you will allow the seeds to germinate. You will then record the number of seeds that have been germinated each day for 3 days. In activity 2, you will prepare by collecting 2 different soil samples. Then, you will determine the buffering capacity of bottled water. Next, you will mix each soil sample with bottled water and allow the mixtures to settle overnight. Then, you will decant the eluent from each soil sample. Finally, you will determine the buffering capacity of each soil sample.

A procedural workflow for activity of the investigation. After completing activity 2, in activity 3, replace the moths in the environment and create allele pairs for the moths. Next, calculate the actual phenotypic and genotypic frequencies, the allelic frequencies and the theoretical genotypic frequencies. Then, remove some of the white moths and calculate the alleles passing to the next generation. Then, determine the alleles present in the next generation. You will complete this for all 4 generations.

data.title: Allele
data.content: One of two or more versions of a gene or DNA sequence

data.title: Allelic frequency
data.content: The relative proportion of alleles for a gene present in the gene pool

data.title: Dominant
data.content: Describes the trait that is expressed when two different alleles are present

data.title: Gene pool
data.content: The sum total of all alleles in all individuals making up the population

data.title: Genetic equilibrium
data.content: The state wherein a population's allelic and genotypic frequencies remain constant over time

data.title: Genotype
data.content: The genetic makeup of an individual cell or organism that determines or contributes to the phenotype

data.title: Heterozygous
data.content: Describes a genotype consisting of two different alleles

data.title: Homozygous
data.content: Describes a genotype consisting of two identical alleles

data.title: Natural selection
data.content: The differential success rate in the reproduction of different phenotypes resulting from the interaction of the organisms with their environment

data.title: Phenotype
data.content: The physical expression of a trait

data.title: Recessive
data.content: Describes the trait that not is expressed when two different alleles are present
